content.raw:
Hi, thank you for this suggestion!

I think this is a great idea and it's absolutely welcome.
I have a couple of questions to make sure I understand how this will work.
After reading the code, my understanding is that the index is dumped to a file only when `prebuild_byte_offset_file` is called explicitly.  Is that correct?
Then, `build_index` will silently try reading the index from the file, but if it fails it falls back onto the old implementation.

If that is the case, I have no objections at all. I think we don't want to try and write index files   by default, but as long as it's only done manually, I think this is fine.

Another question: why do you implement `prebuild_byte_offset_file` as a class method instead of just calling `self._write_byte_offsets` in a regular instance method?

content.raw:
Correct, the index will not be written to file unless explicitly requested by calling `prebuild_byte_offset_file` or `_write_byte_offsets`, and it will silently fall back on the current behavior when that file is missing.

The reason for that class method is because I wanted to be able to in one statement of intent, create the parser and write the offsets to file. This doesn't need to remain part of the API, but then I think `_write_byte_offsets` might make sense as a public method instead of using the _ internal prefix. I'll start wiring this together locally and set up some tests.
